children.name: convertArgument
children.comment:
Converts the given argument Object to js-friendly format, recursively.

Flattens out all Chrome objects into their corresponding ._toMap()
definitions, then converts them to JS objects.

Returns the new argument.

Cannot be used for functions.

children.name: _convertListArgument
children.comment:
Converts the given list-type argument to js-friendly format, recursively.
Returns the new List object.

children.name: _convertMapArgument
children.comment:
Useful functions for converting arguments.


Converts the given map-type argument to js-friendly format, recursively.
Returns the new Map object.

children.name: API_app_runtime
postIntentResponse
children.comment:
postIntentResponse is an internal method to responds to an intent
previously sent to a packaged app. This is identified by intentId, and
should only be invoked at most once per intentId.
Functions

children.name: Event_app_runtime_onRestarted
children.comment:
Fired at Chrome startup to apps that were running when Chrome last shut
down.

children.name: Event_app_runtime_onLaunched
children.comment:
Events

Fired when an app is launched from the launcher or in response to a web
intent.

children.name: intentId
children.comment: Identifies the intent.

children.name: success
children.comment: Was this intent successful? (i.e., postSuccess vs postFailure).

children.name: data
children.comment: Data associated with the intent response.

children.name: id
children.comment: The id of the file handler that the app is being invoked with.

children.name: entry
children.comment: FileEntry for the file.

children.name: type
children.comment: The MIME type of the file.

children.name: AppRuntimeIntent
postResult
children.comment: Callback to be compatible with WebIntents.

children.name: postFailure
children.comment: Callback to be compatible with WebIntents.

children.name: action
children.comment: The WebIntent being invoked.

children.name: type
children.comment: The MIME type of the data.

children.name: data
children.comment: Data associated with the intent.
Types

children.name: API_app_window
create
children.comment:
The size and position of a window can be specified in a number of different ways. The most simple option is not specifying anything at all, in which case a default size and platform dependent position will be used.

Another option is to use the top/left and width/height properties, which will always put the window at the specified coordinates with the specified size.

Yet another option is to give the window a (unique) id. This id is then used to remember the size and position of the window whenever it is moved or resized. This size and position is then used instead of the specified bounds on subsequent opening of a window with the same id. If you need to open a window with an id at a location other than the remembered default, you can create it hidden, move it to the desired location, then show it.

You can also combine these various options, explicitly specifying for example the size while having the position be remembered or other combinations like that. Size and position are dealt with seperately, but individual coordinates are not. So if you specify a top (or left) coordinate, you should also specify a left (or top) coordinate, and similar for size.

If you specify both a regular and a default value for the same option the regular value is the only one that takes effect.

children.name: current
children.comment:
Returns an $ref:AppWindow object for the current script context (ie
JavaScript 'window' object). This can also be called on a handle to a
script context for another page, for example:
otherWindow.chrome.app.window.current().
Functions

children.name: Event_app_window_onRestored
children.comment: Fired when the window is restored from being minimized or maximized.

children.name: Event_app_window_onMinimized
children.comment: Fired when the window is minimized.

children.name: Event_app_window_onMaximized
children.comment: Fired when the window is maximized.

children.name: Event_app_window_onClosed
children.comment: Fired when the window is closed.

children.name: Event_app_window_onBoundsChanged
children.comment:
Events

Fired when the window is resized.

children.name: focus
children.comment: Focus the window.

children.name: minimize
children.comment: Minimize the window.

children.name: isMinimized
children.comment: Is the window minimized?

children.name: maximize
children.comment: Maximize the window.

children.name: isMaximized
children.comment: Is the window maximized?

children.name: restore
children.comment: Restore the window.

children.name: moveTo
children.comment: Move the window to the position (|left|, |top|).

children.name: resizeTo
children.comment: Resize the window to |width|x|height| pixels in size.

children.name: drawAttention
children.comment: Draw attention to the window.

children.name: clearAttention
children.comment: Clear attention to the window.

children.name: close
children.comment: Close the window.

children.name: show
children.comment: Show the window. Does nothing if the window is already visible.

children.name: hide
children.comment: Hide the window. Does nothing if the window is already hidden.

children.name: getBounds
children.comment: Get the window's bounds as a $ref:Bounds object.

children.name: setBounds
children.comment: Set the window's bounds.

children.name: setIcon
children.comment:
Set the app icon for the window (experimental). Currently this is only
being implemented on Ash. TODO(stevenjb): Investigate implementing this on
Windows and OSX.

children.name: contentWindow
children.comment: The JavaScript 'window' object for the created child.

children.name: AppWindowCreateWindowOptions
id
children.comment:
Id to identify the window. This will be used to remember the size and
position of the window and restore that geometry when a window with the
same id (and no explicit size or position) is later opened.

children.name: defaultWidth
children.comment:
Default width of the window. (Deprecated; regular bounds act like this
now.)

children.name: defaultHeight
children.comment:
Default height of the window. (Deprecated; regular bounds act like this
now.)

children.name: defaultLeft
children.comment:
Default X coordinate of the window. (Deprecated; regular bounds act like
this now.)

children.name: defaultTop
children.comment:
Default Y coordinate of the window. (Deprecated; regular bounds act like
this now.)

children.name: width
children.comment: Width of the window. (Deprecated; use 'bounds'.)

children.name: height
children.comment: Height of the window. (Deprecated; use 'bounds'.)

children.name: left
children.comment: X coordinate of the window. (Deprecated; use 'bounds'.)

children.name: top
children.comment: Y coordinate of the window. (Deprecated; use 'bounds'.)

children.name: minWidth
children.comment: Minimum width of the window.

children.name: minHeight
children.comment: Minimum height of the window.

children.name: maxWidth
children.comment: Maximum width of the window.

children.name: maxHeight
children.comment: Maximum height of the window.

children.name: type
children.comment:
Window type:  'shell' - the default window type  'panel' - a panel, managed
by the OS (Currently experimental, Ash only)

children.name: frame
children.comment: Frame type: 'none' or 'chrome' (defaults to 'chrome').

children.name: bounds
children.comment:
Size of the content in the window (excluding the titlebar). If specified in
addition to any of the left/top/width/height parameters, this field takes
precedence. If a frameBounds is specified, the frameBounds take precedence.

children.name: transparentBackground
children.comment:
Enable window background transparency. Only supported in ash. Requires
experimental API permission.

children.name: hidden
children.comment:
If true, the window will be created in a hidden state. Call show() on the
window to show it once it has been created. Defaults to false.

children.name: singleton
children.comment:
By default if you specify an id for the window, the window will only be
created if another window with the same id doesn't already exist. If a
window with the same id already exists that window is activated instead. If
you do want to create multiple windows with the same id, you can set this
property to false.
Types

children.name: Event
addListener
children.comment: Registers an event listener callback to an event.

children.name: removeListener
children.comment: Deregisters an event listener callback from an event.

children.name: hasListener
children.comment: Returns True if callback is registered to the event.

children.name: hasListeners
children.comment: Returns true if any event listeners are registered to the event.

children.name: addRules
children.comment:
Registers rules to handle events.

[eventName] is the name of the event this function affects and [rules] are
the rules to be registered. These do not replace previously registered
rules. [callback] is called with registered rules.

children.name: getRules
children.comment:
Returns currently registered rules.

[eventName] is the name of the event this function affects and, if an array
is passed as [ruleIdentifiers], only rules with identifiers contained in
this array are returned. [callback] is called with registered rules.

children.name: removeRules
children.comment:
Unregisters currently registered rules.

[eventName] is the name of the event this function affects and, if an array
is passed as [ruleIdentifiers], only rules with identifiers contained in
this array are unregistered. [callback] is called when the rules are
unregistered.

children.name: Rule
children.comment: Description of a declarative rule for handling events.

children.name: ChromeObject
children.comment:
Native wrappers for the Chrome Packaged App APIs.

These functions allow direct access to the Packaged App APIs, allowing
Chrome Packaged Apps to be written using Dart.

For more information on these APIs, see the Chrome.* APIs Documentation:
  http://developer.chrome.com/extensions/api_index.html

A set of utilities for use with the Chrome Extension APIs.

Allows for easy access to required JS objects.


A dart object, that is convertible to JS. Used for creating objects in dart,
then passing them to JS.

Objects that are passable to JS need to implement this interface.
